<u>May18.1738<\u> pr. no. 443.
the Quantity of Lichen to that of the pepper.
This difference in ye proportions must be left to 
the judgement of practitioner’s; but upon the 
authority of another minute in the Society’s 
Journal Books, it may not be improper to 
make an addition to the abovemention’d 
<u>Dampier’s powder <\u>
“March 7.1671/2. Sr. Robt. Moray mention’d 
“that a whole Kennel of Dogs belonging to 
“his Royal Highness were bitten by a mad Dog
“& had been lately cured by a certain herb 
“called <u>Stellaria <\u> or Star of ye Earth.
This plant is the <u>Lychnis viscosa, flore muscoso<\u>
Casp. Bauhin. in English <u>Spanish catch fly.<\u>
See these Trans. no. 187. where is a <u>Receipt <\u> <s>for ye <\s>
<u>to cure <s>of <\u> the Bite of <\s> <u>Mad Dogs &c<\u>. wherein this 
Plant is a principall Ingredient; <u>wch <\u> Receipt 
communicated by Sr. Robt. Gourdon was there published by <u>his Majesty’s [speciall]
command <\u> anno 1687.
Wherefore suppose the Composition were to 
be thus 
Take ash-colour’d Ground-Liver-wort 
Black Pepper, & the herb Spanish 
catch fly all finely powder’d of each two Drachms: <s>finely <\s>
for 4 doses, to be taken as 
Dampier prescribes in his letter in these Trans.
no. 237.
Ent’d in R.B.
